body:
Started working on this and unsurprisingly realized that how `config.options.verbose` is used currently is a bit complicated. So I took the time to see all the places that it is used. The following was based off [6c2feb75d](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/tree/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf) (current head of main):

## General Summary
The vast majority of uses of the verbose setting are within [_pytest.terminal](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py). In addition to using it directly, `TerminalReporter` also [re-exposes it as a property](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L389-L392). The `pytest` code base does not use the property outside of the `TerminalReporter` class.

* `TerminalReporter` is exposed to
plugins as part of the `pytest_terminal_summary()` hook.
* The `Config` object is also exposed to plugins: Either directly in a hook ([example](https://docs.pytest.org/en/7.4.x/reference/reference.html#pytest.hookspec.pytest_make_parametrize_id)) or indirectly ([example](https://docs.pytest.org/en/7.4.x/reference/reference.html#pytest.Item.config))

## Uses of `config.options.verbose` outside of `TerminalReporter`

* [cacheprovider.pytest_report_header()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/cacheprovider.py#L543): >0 display cachedir path (always displayed if not using default chachedir path)
* [assertions.truncate._should_truncate_item()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/truncate.py#L27-L30): truncate full explanation if < 2 or NOT running in CI
* [assertions.uti.assertrepr_compare()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L164) (accessed add passed down to other function)
  * \> 1: [call saferepr_unlimited()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L174) for left & right expressions
  * <= 1: [call saferepr](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L180) for left & right expressions (maxsize depends on operator string)
  * passed into _compare_eq_any() and _notin_text() (which continue to pass down to other compare functions)
  * [_diff_text()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L247): <1 trim long sequences of leading or trailing identical characters
  * [_compare_eq_cls()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L449): <2 omit identical items
    * recurses into _compare_eq_any()
  * [_compare_eq_sequence()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L338): (passed in, but unused)
  * [_compare_eq_set()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L391): (passed in, but unused)
  * [_compare_eq_dict()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L416):
    * < 2: omit identical items
    * else: list common items
  * [_compare_eq_iterable()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/util.py#L310): <=0 (and NOT running in CI) don't diff pretty print of objects
* [logging.pytest_runtestloop()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/logging.py#L763-L765): value forced to 1 if ((`--log-cli-level` is provided or `log_cli` is set) AND terminalreporter plugin exists)
  * I haven't looked into the deeper implications of this

## Uses of `config.getoption("verbose")`

* [cacheprovider.pytest_report_collectionfinish()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/cacheprovider.py#L316): >= 0 (and active) return report status
* [logging.pytest_runtestloop()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/logging.py#L763-L765): < 1
  * See `config.options.verbose` usage
* [nodes.Node._repr_failure_py()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/nodes.py#L470): > 1 don't truncate locals for exception info representation.
* [python.importtestmodule()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/python.py#L544): < 2 filter traceback information
* [stepwise.pytest_report_collectionfinish()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/stepwise.py#L121-L121): >= 0 return report status
* [asserstions.rewrite._get_maxsize_for_saferepr()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/assertion/rewrite.py#L429):
  * \>= 2: no max size
  * \>= 1: `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE` * 10
  * else: `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE`

## Uses of `config.options.verbose` in `TerminalReporter`

* [pytest_runtest_logreport()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L605):
  * <2 - possibly trimmed skipped reason
  * 2>= full skipped reason
* [pytest_collection()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L692-L696):
  * if atty terminal and >= 0 write "collecting..."
  * if >=1 write "collecting..."
* [report_collect()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L709): <0 exit early instead of writing summary count line
* [pytest_collection_finish()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L811): if `--collect-only` passed and the session has item, > -1 write empty line before printing collected items 
* [_printcollecteditems()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L821): (only called if `--collect-only`) 
  * < 0: 
    * if < -1 write out summary of items (filename & count)
    * else write out each collected item. (filename & item name)
  * else: tree view of each item
    * \>= 1: include docstring

## Uses of the `TerminalReporter.verbosity` property
[A read-only property](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L390-L392) exposed by TerminalReporter that exposes `config.options.verbose`

* [_locationline()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L913):
  * < 2: relative path from nodeid (if fspath is non-empty string)
  * \>= 2: same as above, but add " <- {bestrelpath(...)}" if fspath doesn't match node id
* [pytest_runtest_logfinish()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L640): <= 0 show line ending progress info (if [showing progress info](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L368))
* [pytest_runtest_logreport()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L567): <= 0 write just the result letter instead of calling `_locationline()`
* [pytest_sessionstart()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L746C14-L746C14): > 0 include "-- {executable name}" in first line of session header (or debug or pastebin)
* [showfspath](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L407-L410): return (verbosity >= 0) if self._showfspath is not set
  * only used in [pytest_runtest_logstart()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L563) and only if `showlongtestinfo` is `False`
* [showheader](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L395): return (verbosity >= 0)
  * only used in [pytest_sessionstart()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L749)
* [showlongtestinfo](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L417C5-L417C5): return (verbosity > 0)
  * only used in [pytest_runtest_logstart()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L559)
* [summary_stats()](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/6c2feb75d2c4bb01aa145f8b85f7fb09fe4133cf/src/_pytest/terminal.py#L1095):
  * < -1: don't write anything
  * \>= 0: include full width seperator in addition to stats message

## Others

* `PYTEST_DEBUG` - When set, pytest will print tracing and debug information.
* `--no-header` & `--no-summary`: explicitly disable to named terminal output component.

That reference is helpful to understand what things accessing verbosity and how. But it's not the easiest to understand the full behavior. So I went through and documented the behavior by verbosity level. (This helped me get a better understanding of specific aspects that can be controlled.)

## -2

* assertions
  * truncate full explanation (if not in CI)
  * abbreviate left & right repr
  * string compares - trim long sequences of leading or trailing identical characters
  * data object compares - omit identical items
  * dict compares - omit identical items
  * iterable compares - diff pretty print of objects (if in CI)
* filter tracebacks
* rewrite maxsize = `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE`
* (if `--collect-only`) write filenames and count of items in file
* write result letter instead of item location

## -1

* assertions
  * truncate full explanation (if not in CI)
  * abbreviate left & right repr
  * string compares - trim long sequences of leading or trailing identical characters
  * data object compares - omit identical items
  * dict compares - omit identical items
  * iterable compares - diff pretty print of objects (if in CI)
* filter tracebacks
* rewrite maxsize = `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE`
* (if `--collect-only`) write each item (filename and item name)
* write result letter instead of item location
* write summary stats

## 0

* assertions
  * truncate full explanation (if not in CI)
  * abbreviate left & right repr
  * string compares - trim long sequences of leading or trailing identical characters
  * data object compares - omit identical items
  * dict compares - omit identical items
  * iterable compares - diff pretty print of objects (if in CI)
* write cache report (if active)
* write stepwise report (if active)
* filter tracebacks
* rewrite maxsize = `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE`
* (if atty terminal) write "collecting..."
* write collection report
* (if `--collect-only`) write tree view of each item
* write result letter instead of item location
* write line ending progress info (if showing progress info)
* write file path for module once before result letters for test cases in module
* write summary stats with full width separator

## 1

* write cache dir
* write executable path
* assertions
  * truncate full explanation (if not in CI)
  * abbreviate left & right repr
  * string compares - trim long sequences of leading or trailing identical characters
  * data object compares - omit identical items
  * dict compares - omit identical items
  * iterable compares - diff pretty print of objects
* write cache report (if active)
* write stepwise report (if active)
* filter tracebacks
* rewrite maxsize = `DEFAULT_REPR_MAX_SIZE` * 10
* write "collecting..."
* write collection report
* (if `--collect-only`) write tree view of each item with docstring
* write item location for each item
* write trimmed (if necessary) skip reason
* write summary stats with full width separator

### 2

* write cache dir
* write executable path
* assertions
  * full left & right repr
  * string compares - no trimming
  * data object compares - all items listed
  * dict compares - all items listed
  * iterable compares - diff pretty print of objects
* write cache report (if active)
* write stepwise report (if active)
* no rewrite maxsize
* write "collecting..."
* write collection report
* (if `--collect-only`) write tree view of each item with docstring
* write item location for each item
* write full skip reason
* write summary stats with full width separator
I completely missed `assertions.util` on the first pass (oops). I updated the previous comments with the missing details.

issue.title: Add OuputVerbosity and use it in assertions

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for submitting a PR, your contribution is really appreciated!

Here is a quick checklist that should be present in PRs.

- [X] Include documentation when adding new features.
- [X] Include new tests or update existing tests when applicable.
- [X] Allow maintainers to push and squash when merging my commits. Please uncheck this if you prefer to squash the commits yourself.

If this change fixes an issue, please:

- [ ] Add text like ``closes #XYZW`` to the PR description and/or commits (where ``XYZW`` is the issue number). See the [github docs](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword) for more information.

Unless your change is trivial or a small documentation fix (e.g., a typo or reword of a small section) please:

- [X] Create a new changelog file in the `changelog` folder, with a name like `<ISSUE NUMBER>.<TYPE>.rst`. See [changelog/README.rst](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/main/changelog/README.rst) for details.

  Write sentences in the **past or present tense**, examples:

  * *Improved verbose diff output with sequences.*
  * *Terminal summary statistics now use multiple colors.*

  Also make sure to end the sentence with a `.`.

- [X] Add yourself to `AUTHORS` in alphabetical order.
-->

`OuputVerbosity` is a new class that allows for retrieving a verbosity level for a specific output type. If nothing is specifically configured, the application wide verbose value is used.

The first use of this functionality is `verbosity_assertions` which can be used to make the assertion reports output at the most verbose level while still showing a single character for each test case when progress is being reported.


Addresses #11387

issue.body:
This is a follow on to fine-grained output verbosity for assertions (#11387/#11473). The next "category" that seems to stand out based on the [current behavior](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/11387#issuecomment-1729291056) is how `pytest` displays test cases are it executes them. By this I mean the distinction between:


`--quiet`
```
................................................................................. [  2%]
................................................................................. [  4%]
<truncated>
```
vs

default
```
testing/acceptance_test.py .....                                                  [  0%]
testing/deprecated_test.py ..........                                             [  0%]
testing/test_argcomplete.py ..                                                    [  0%]
<truncated>
```

vs

`--verbose`
```
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestGeneralUsage::test_docstring_on_hookspec PASSED [  0%]
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_invoke_with_invalid_type PASSED [  0%]
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_invoke_plugin_api PASSED [  0%]
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_core_backward_compatibility PASSED [  0%]
<truncated>
```

Additionally, I think this would also extend to the output of `--collect-only` (doesn't show all of the states):

`--quiet --quiet`
```
testing/_py/test_local.py: 183
testing/acceptance_test.py: 84
testing/code/test_code.py: 17
<truncated>
```
vs

default
```
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestGeneralUsage::test_docstring_on_hookspec
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_invoke_with_invalid_type
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_invoke_plugin_api
testing/acceptance_test.py::TestInvocationVariants::test_core_backward_compatibility
<truncated>
```
---
There doesn't seem to be an existing name for this, so I plan to start the work using `test_case`. If someone comes up with a better name, I'd be happy to use that. I don't think there would be anything else that would fit into this "category". But feel free to bring things to my attention if I missed something.

issue.title: Separate terminal verbosity from diff verbosity

labels.name: type: proposal
labels.description: proposal for a new feature, often to gather opinions or design the API around the new feature

labels.name: topic: reporting
labels.description: related to terminal output and user-facing messages and errors

labels.name: topic: config
labels.description: related to config handling, argument parsing and config file

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Currently `-v` controls both terminal verbosity (how to display test session progress in the terminal) and diff verbosity (how verbose is our diffs when assertions fail).

I've often wanted to increase diff verbosity while also keeping terminal verbosity at the normal level, but this is not possible today.

## Proposal

Introduce a *new* option that controls only *diff* verbosity (for discussion here `-dv`, but please let's bikeshed on this).

For backward compatibility reasons, `-v` keeps controlling both terminal verbosity *and* diff verbosity, but `-dv` can be used to increase diff verbosity independently. 

* `-v`: when used, increase both terminal verbosity and diff verbosity.
* `-dv`: when used, increase diff verbosity only (we also need the equivalent of `-q` for diff verbosity).

With `-dv` in place, we might even consider changing to a higher level of diff verbosity in the future by default, but that remains to be seen.

Related: #6292, #5192

issue.body:
At least I think it is pytest. I'm not 100% sure since I couldn't fix it.
When the tools/test/test_depsolve.py failed when running osbuild_depsolve_dnf5 it would print the contents of the subprocess variables, including stdout which includes a traceback (from osbuild_depsolve_dnf5) wrapped in json. The string is a bit long, and something is chopping out the middle and replacing it with '...'
If I manually trigger failures in the script the json wrapped traceback is fine.
If I run pytest tools manually it is missing the middle part, which ends up being the part telling you what line failed :)
I tried running pytest with `--tb=long` or `--full-traceback` and didn't get any more of the output.
So I'm currently stumped as to what's replacing that part of the string with `...`

body: Should this really have been closed, since (from what I can gather) only a small part of the proposal is implemented so far?

I would love the ability to disable the full width separators and right-aligned elements (like `[100%]`), while keeping the normal verbosity. I frequently resize my terminal windows (via tmux `-Z`), which results in a lot of unaesthetic line-wrapping from pytest when going from wider terminal window to a smaller one.

At the very least a way to configure a max width would help. Right now this is sort of possible with `COLUMNS=80 pytest`, but it would be nice to have it built in to pytest. I would go so far as to say that, as a general rule, well-behaved CLI tools that log output like test runners (as opposed ones that take over the screen like `vim`) should not deliberately try to log full-width lines so that their output doesn't look corrupted when the terminal width shrinks.
